prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the story is in the wrong for breaking up with their fiancé. The situation is that they've been together for 7 years, have a child, and there's been ongoing issues with the fiancé contacting an old friend, a girl he knew for most of his life. The author discovered that even after promises to cut contact, the fiancé kept liking her and her sister's social media posts, and recently unblocked them again.

First, I need to evaluate the key points. The main issue is the fiancé's continued contact with another woman despite the author's insistence that he stop. There's no direct evidence of cheating, just ongoing contact that the author finds unacceptable. The author snooped through the phone, which might be a point of contention. However, given the context of a long-term relationship with trust issues, it's understandable why the author would feel the need to check.

The fiancé's actions—liking ex-girlfriend's pictures, not deleting her, unblocking her again—show a pattern of not respecting the author's boundaries. Even if he claims it's accidental, the repeated nature suggests intentionality. The author felt that despite the fiancé's promises, he wasn't following through, leading to the decision to end the relationship.

Now, considering if the author is in the wrong. The fiancé's behavior is the main issue here. The author's response is based on the breach of trust and lack of respect for boundaries. While snooping might be questionable, the outcome is valid because the fiancé didn't keep his word. The author isn't at fault for leaving when there's a pattern of betrayal, even if it's not outright cheating. The emotional impact of constant infidelity in communication is significant. So the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong.
